H0.text: Metal is always hotter than wood, which explains why, after a few minutes of stirring a pot of hot soup, the metal spoon feels hotter than the wooden spoon.

H1.text: Metal conducts heat better than wood, explaining why the metal spoon feels hotter than the wooden spoon after a few minutes of stirring a pot of hot soup.

H2.text: Metal conducts electricity better than wood, which explains why the metal spoon feels hotter than the wooden spoon after a few minutes of stirring a pot of hot soup.

H3.text: Metal heats up the water better than the wood explains why, after a few minutes of stirring a pot of hot soup, a metal spoon feels hotter than a wooden spoon.

A4.text: Metals have this high thermal conductivity due to free electrons facilitating heat transfer.

A5.text: Silver conducted heat far the best of all other metals, next to this was copper, then gold, tin, iron, steel, Lead.
